coursePhilosophy: Learning to teach mathematics requires more than surviving in classroom. Requires gaining experience thinking about important mathematical ideas and planning learning activities for student understanding through reflection on experiences to create pedagogical foundation for lifelong teaching process.
courseObjectives: Gain experience and knowledge about students' mathematical thinking and understanding
Design and teach mathematics lessons engaging students in exploring and understanding important mathematical ideas
Understand overall expectations of a public-school teacher

courseGrading.determination: University supervisor with input from cooperating teacher and demonstrating competency in all BYU Professional Teacher Candidate Rubric (TCA) areas and passing EDA score (80% or higher)
courseGrading.feedback: Formative rather than summative (comments rather than points)
courseGrading.factors: Quality and consistency of work large factor in professionalism/competence determination

attendance.importance: Critical for student teaching capstone experience
attendance.policy: BYU policy requires full-time students as teachers in classrooms with same commitment as employed teachers
attendance.requirement: Keep contracted teacher days and hours from semester beginning to end
attendance.absences: Must be approved in advance; may result in additional time to experience
attendance.sickness: Notify both cooperating teacher and university supervisor

courseExpectations.extracurriculars: Expected to do extracurricular activities as appropriate for content area
courseExpectations.competencies: Must meet all required stated competencies as measured by BYU assessments

writingToLearn.overview: Writing component accompanies most learning-to-teach activities

rationale.reason: Teachers are communicators; develop facility to communicate about mathematics, learning, and teaching through writing
Build knowledge by sharing it; writing requires seeking connections among concepts and articulating them, leading to deeper exploration
Writing is lens on understanding; colleagues judge competence partly on writing quality as evidence of knowledge

learningToTeachActivities.overview: Majority of assignments done during first half of field experience

dailyJournal.description: Brief writing assignments on social/socio-mathematical norms, mathematical/pedagogical conversations, student mathematical thinking
dailyJournal.submission: Weekly collection on Learning Suite at end of each week
dailyJournal.value: Constant reminder to keep eyes and ears open for insights

components: Make list of classroom and school resources with mentor teacher
Do getting-to-know-you activity for each class
gettingToKnowStudents.deliverable: 2-3 page paper including resources summary, student learnings, specific student examples, email to parents, implications for teaching
gettingToKnowStudents.approval: Get mentor teacher approval for any surveys

observationRecord.description: Detailed notes on particular lesson aspects
observationRecord.selection: Choose two lessons each week - one from cooperating teacher, one from another teacher
observationRecord.submission: Due Saturday with 1-2 page synthesis and implications for own teaching

lessonPlans.timing: Each week observed by university supervisor
lessonPlans.submission: At least night before teaching to supervisor
lessonPlans.flexibility: Any form acceptable but must include FMC, learning goals, task description, launch/explore/discuss, anticipated student thinking and questions

teachObserveReflect.structure: Teach or observe peer student teachers, participate in reflection meetings
teachObserveReflect.planning: Plan lesson together with peer student teacher using chosen template
teachObserveReflect.teaching: Teach individual classes; distribute lesson plan copies to observers
teachObserveReflect.observation: Observers take notes on lesson plan about student responses - focus on student thinking not presentation
teachObserveReflect.reflection: Reflection meeting with peer sharing observations, goals, questions, then supervisor/cooperating teacher lead discussion on pedagogical principles

week3.activity: One peer tapes lesson; both watch, look for student thinking evidence, discuss together
week3.deliverable: 1-2 paragraph summary of observations and goals for next lesson by Saturday

week4.activity: Other peer tapes lesson; both watch for question types and who responded, discuss together
week4.deliverable: 1-2 paragraph summary of observations and goals for next lesson by Saturday

studentInterview.preparation: Observe student in classroom; note what they do/say, imagine their experience
studentInterview.process: Audio record interview; ask student to explain reasoning, avoid teaching
studentInterview.followup: Can provide help after interview based on insights
studentInterview.deliverable: 2-3 page paper characterizing student's mathematical experience/understanding, discussing needs for increased understanding

week2: Paper on Student's Classroom Experience observations
Getting to know your students paper
weeklyAssignments.weeks6to13: Take over teaching; send lesson plan for observed lessons
week14: Gradually transition classes back to mentor teacher
Cluster student teachers lessons observations with digital dialogue prompt reflection

honorCode.standard: Students expected to be honest in all academic work
honorCode.definition: Work presented as your own must in fact be your own work, not another's
honorCode.violation: May result in failing grade and additional university disciplinary action
honorCode.dressAndGrooming: Expected to adhere to Dress and Grooming Standards

sexualMisconduct.prohibition: Title IX prohibits unlawful sex discrimination and sexual harassment in education programs
sexualMisconduct.scope: Includes sexual violence, dating violence, domestic violence, stalking on basis of sex

reporting.mandatory: All faculty in teaching/supervisory role must report incidents
reporting.coordinator: Title IX Coordinator at t9coordinator@byu.edu or (801) 422-8692
reporting.resources: Confidential Victim Advocate and non-confidential resources available

studentDisability.commitment: BYU committed to providing working and learning atmosphere with reasonable accommodations
studentDisability.definition: Disability is physical or mental impairment substantially limiting major life activities
studentDisability.assessment: UAC can assess students for learning, attention, and emotional concerns
